Graphical abstract Direct conversion of syngas (CO + H2) toward aromatics has been demonstrated over a hybrid catalyst system composed of Fe-based FTS catalyst and HZSM-5 zeolite. Over the catalyst system, the aromatics were highly selective in the liquid hydrocarbon products with a content greater than 95%, and 70–90% of the aromatics were concentered on the toluene, xylene and 3C-branched alkylbenzenes. In this study, we systematically investigated the effects of reaction conditions (temperature, pressure, space velocity and H2/CO ratio) and catalyst combination (Si/Al ratio of zeolite, weight ratio of HZSM-5 to Fe-based catalyst, metal modification of HZSM-5, and kind of Fe-based catalyst) on the CO conversion, selectivity to aromatics, aromatic distribution, and catalyst deactivation, combining with some characterization technologies (XRD, BET, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, TG and 27Al NMR). The obtained results show that HZSM-5 zeolite was the crucial component for aromatic formation. Excessive loading of the zeolite in bed would greatly suppress the carburization of reduced Fe into Fe carbides as well as CO dissociation on the Fe carbides because of the increasingly unfavorable direct contact between the acidic HZSM-5 and Fe-based catalyst, resulting in a remarkably lower CO conversion. HZSM-5 zeolite having high Brønsted acidity favored the formation of aromatics with a high content in liquid phase. However, as HZSM-5 had originally lower Brønsted acidity or the Brønsted acidity decreased during the aromatic synthesis due to more coke deposition, the selectivity to hydrocarbons in liquid phase gradually shifted to iso-paraffins rather than aromatics. Reactions operated over FeMn-HZSM-5 catalyst system at lower temperature or higher pressure led to an easier deactivation of HZSM-5 mainly from coke deposition. Compared with the FeMn-HZSM-5, FeK-HZSM-5 deactivated seriously at same conditions probably due to heavier and olefinic primary hydrocarbons over the FeK catalyst. In addition, 27Al NMR showed that extraction of framework Al by in situ formed H2O and CO2 could be ignorable for the HZSM-5 deactivation. More detailed results and discussion from abundant experimental work on clarifying their effects on the aromatic synthesis can be found in the article. Keywords Syngas Aromatic hydrocarbons F-T synthesis Fe-based catalysts HZSM-5 zeolites 1 Introduction After light olefins (C2–C4) only, aromatics including benzene, toluene and xylene (BTX) are important and fundamental feedstocks for producing in bulk of plastic, pesticide, dye, solvent and etc., and their market demand is growing steadily. More than 90% of aromatics, however, are produced from petroleum oil in the technologies of joint productions of light olefins and fuel, for example, catalytic reforming of naphtha and hydrocarbon pyrolysis [1,2]. Recently, the market share for producing of light olefins has been gradually occupied by nonpetroleum resources, like coal-based methanol [3] and light alkanes separated from abundant shale gas [4], which certainly shocks the traditional oil-based olefin and aromatic markets. On the other hand, the concerns on the depletion of oil reserves have stimulated and driven more investigation of alternative and sustainable processes for production of aromatics, especially the BTX. CH4 dehydroaromatization over Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst is a promising route for benzene formation due to extremely high selectivity to aromatics which can be greater than 80% [5]. Although the process has been verified by circulating fluidized bed reactor in laboratory [6], there are still big challenges in industry in solving of the rapid catalyst deactivation, raising one-pass CH4 conversion and choosing of suitable reactor materials for high operation temperature (larger than 1073 K). Aromatization of light olefins and alkanes (C2–C8) over zeolites or metal-modified zeolites [7] is an optional industrialized process for replenishment of aromatics, but this process sacrifices the precious olefins products and its scale greatly depends on the supplying of alkanes resources from refinery plant. Coal, natural gas and biomass-based methanol-to-aromatic (MTA) process [8] has been widely focused on in recent years, and a 10,000 t/a pilot scale test was said to be run successfully in China. However, the profit of MTA process might be much sensitive to the relative price among coal, oil, methanol and aromatics in world market [9]. Paralleled to MTA process, dimethyl ether-to-aromatic (DMTA) [10] and other alcohols-to-aromatic, such as ethanol [11], sorbitol [12] and isobutyl alcohol [13], are also paid close attention to in recent years. Instead of the process of syngas-methanol-aromatic, direct synthesis of aromatics from syngas (CO/H2) would certainly be a more competitive route because of its short process flow in which one-pass CO conversion can reach 100% thermodynamically and the required H2/CO ratio can be low (<2) and the investment and cost in formation and separation of CH3OH could be greatly cut down. Different from the Kölbel-Engelhardt (KE) process in which aromatic could be directly synthesized from CO/H2O over Ni-based catalysts [14], for the traditional Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) from CO/H2 over Fe-based and Co-based catalysts, however, rather than aromatics but olefin/paraffins and alcohols are the common formations [15–18], according to the FTS mechanism. Coupling of zeolite catalysts for further aromatization of the FTS products, therefore, seems to be necessary. Recently, several papers have dealt with the process using a dual-bed reactor system in which two catalysts of different functions placed in series [19–21]. For example, the syngas can be converted into aromatic-containing hydrocarbons in two separated reactors where one charged with Cu/Zn/Al2O3 catalysts and the other one with Mn-modified HZSM-5 zeolite via syngas-DME-aromatic at different conditions [19]. Also, combination of two different catalysts into a single reactor can lead the transformation of syngas into aromatics [22–25]. Early work by Guan et al. [22] reported a hybrid catalyst system of MnO supported Fe-based FTS catalyst and Ga/HZSM-5 catalyst for the reaction at mild conditions. Specially, the HZSM-5-supported Mo/HZSM-5 [26] and Pd-promoted Fe/HZSM-5 [27] catalysts can directly provide activity for synthesis of aromatics from syngas while the required operation pressures were relatively high (3.5–9 MPa) for obtaining of high CO conversion. In fact, it is a basic idea of combination of FTS catalysts with HZSM-5 zeolite used for conversion of syngas into gasoline-ranged hydrocarbons, a mixture of iso-paraffins and aromatic [28,29]. However, it is much difficult to obtain high selectivity to aromatic as the main target, especially the BTX formations, over a hybrid catalysts system or a single catalyst, because the optimal conditions (temperature and pressure) for FTS and aromatization or isomerization reactions might not be matched well. For example, the working temperatures for FTS and aromatization over zeolite are suggested to be among 473–623 K and around 773 K, respectively. In this regard, the Co-based FTS catalysts could not be considered as the candidate for combination with zeolite in a single-bed reactor, because the optimal operating temperature for the catalyst in the FTS is lower than 523 K [30], and if the temperature is larger than 573 K the products are mainly C1–C4 alkanes, especially the CH4. Therefore, Fe-based FTS catalyst seems to be the best choice in a single-bed reactor, and the high-temperature Fe-based FTS benefits its matching with the process of aromatic formation and a better recovery of the FT reaction heat for steam generation. Besides the basic reaction conditions including temperature, pressure, space velocity and the ratio of H2/CO, the selectivity to aromatics and the aromatic distribution may essentially depend on the factors in catalyst combination, such as the Si/Al ratio of zeolite, weight of zeolite, and the kind of Fe-based catalyst. For Fe-based FTS catalysts, light olefins or/and paraffins are considered to be crucial to aromatic formation. In most cases, while alkali like K is an optional promoter for increasing the selectivity to olefins over Fe-based FTS catalysts, however, migration of the alkali to acid sites of zeolite due to alkali redistribution in the high-temperature FTS [31] could lower the activity of zeolite for aromatic formation [32]. Therefore, the kind of Fe catalyst with proper additives would be an important variable for obtaining of different olefin/paraffin ratios at different carbon number [33], and the formed hydrocarbons could show different activity toward aromatic over zeolites. Ideally, over a model catalyst or a hybrid catalyst system for achieving of a high selectivity to aromatic from syngas, it is expected that transition state species of hydrocarbons (C2–C5) formed at Fe active sites can move to Brønsted acid sites in the zeolite channels for completing of the aromatization rapidly, leaving little possibility for CH4 formation and their excessive chain propagation. Although a few of publications have shown the possibility of conversion of syngas into aromatic over a hybrid catalyst system [24,34,35] or in a dual-bed reactor system [19], design of an excellent catalyst still lacks of detailed information for demonstrating the effects of several factors on the aromatic formation and distribution. For example, the various Fe-based catalysts can provide variable selectivity to olefins and paraffins and on the other hand, may have negative interaction with zeolite as they combine. Therefore, in this study, we systematically investigated the effects of reaction conditions and catalyst combination on the aromatic synthesis over hybrid catalyst first. The aim of the study is to clarify their effects on the aromatic hydrocarbons synthesis for further flexible controlling of the aromatic formation and distribution and also for future catalyst design. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation FeMn catalyst with a Fe/Mn wdieight ratio of 96:4 was prepared by co-precipitation of a solution of Fe(NO3)3 and Mn(NO3)2 using a precipitator of aqueous ammonia (1 mol/L) at a condition of pH = 8, T = 333 K and a continuous stirring. The resulting solution was allowed to stand at room temperature for 1 h, followed by filtering and washing with deionized water for 3 times, and then drying at 393 K for 12 h and calcination at 773 K for 5 h. The obtained powder was pressed, crushed and sieved into the particles with a size range of 250–425 μm for use. In addition, precipitated Fe was prepared using the same procedure above. Further, K was introduced to the Fe catalyst to prepare a 99.2Fe0.8K catalyst using incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method [33,36]. Besides, a supported 10wt%Fe/TiO2 also prepared using IWI method. HZSM-5 zeolites with a Si/Al ratio range of 12.5–150 were supplied by Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd., China. 2 wt% Zn, Ga, Cu and Zr modified HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method. The zeolites and modified zeolites were all calcinated at 773 K for 5 h before use. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were recorded on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) over a 2θ range of 5–90° at a scanning rate of 0.05°/s. BET surface areas of catalyst samples as well as their pore volumes were measured by BET method from N2 adsorption at 87 K in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 system. Prior to the adsorption measurements, all samples were vacuum-degassed at 673 K for 5 h to remove adsorbed moisture from their surfaces. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis of spent HZSM-5 samples were carried out on a Mettler-Toledo TGA-1100SF Thermogravimetric analyzer for estimating coke amount in zeolite. 27Al NMR spectrum of HZSM-5 and spent HZSM-5 samples were obtained on a Bruker AVANCE III 400 WB spectrometer at B0  = 9.4 T. The corresponding resonance frequency of 27Al was 104.3 MHz. Samples were packed in a 4 mm ZrO2 rotor and spun at the magic angle (54.7°), and the spin rate was 12 kHz. Single pulse magic angle spinning spectra were acquired using a high power 0.4 μs pulse, corresponding to a tip angle of 15° and a recycle delay of 1 s. The 27Al chemical shift was externally referenced to a 1.0 mol/L aqueous solution of Al(NO3)3. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) profiles of catalyst samples were performed on a Chemstar automated chemisorption analyzer. A 100 mg sample of a catalyst was used for each test. The sample was first treated in a N2 stream of 50 mL/min at 573 K for 3 h, cooled down to 323 K and subjected to a 2000 ppm NH3/Ar stream for 30 min. After that, the NH3 adsorbed sample was treated in an Ar stream of 50 mL/min at 323 K for 2 h and then heated to 1073 K in the same stream at a heating rate of 10 K/min for desorption of NH3. The desorbed NH3 was detected and analyzed by a TCD detector. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments of catalyst samples were conducted in an auto-controlled flow reactor system (TP-5076, Tianjin Xianquan Instrument, Co., Ltd., China) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 50 mg of a catalyst sample was charged in a quartz-tube reactor and pretreated in a N2 stream at 473 K for 1 h and then cooled down to 303 K. After that, the sample was heated in a 30 mL/min flow of 5%H2/N2 to 1173 K at a rate of 10 K/min to obtain the H2-TPR pattern. 2.3 Catalytic test In most of tests, 0.5 g of Fe-based catalyst particles and 0.5 g of HZSM-5 zeolite were mixed well and diluted with quartz sand (125 μm–180 μm) at a volume rate of 1:2 and then charged into a steel fixed bed reactor (i.d. 8 mm). In some special tests for investigating the effect of the ratio of HZSM-5 to FeMn on aromatic synthesis, the weight of FeMn catalyst was fixed to be 0.5 g while that of HZSM-5 was ranged from 0.25 g to 2.5 g to obtained a varied ratio. Prior to a test, the catalyst bed was heated to 393 K in a H2 stream of 37 mL/min (0.1 MPa) and kept there for 0.5 h, then further heated to 723 K in the same H2 stream with a heating rate of 2 K/min and maintained the condition for 3 h. After the reduction, the temperature of catalyst bed was controlled to decrease to 523 K in the same H2 stream, and soon a 3%N2/48.5%CO/48.5%H2 feed stream of 18.5–74 mL/min was switched to flow the catalyst bed and the reaction pressure was adjusted to 0.2–3.0 MPa. Then, the temperature of the catalytic bed was carefully raised to the reaction temperature of 553–623 K within 30–40 min. The effluent gas out from the reactor was cooled and trapped by ice-water (270 K) first, and the uncondensable gas was then sampled into two loops and analyzed on-line by a gas chromatography (GC14B, Shimadzu) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID) while the collected condensate hydrocarbons was analyzed off-line by another gas chromatography (GC-2014A, Shimadzu) equipped with a HP-1 capillary column and a FID after the end of the test. For the uncondensable gas, the compounds of CO, CO2, N2 (an internal standard substance), and CH4 were separated by a TDX-01 packed column (3 mm × 2 m) and the hydrocarbons of C1–C5 were separated by an HP-PLOT/Al2O3 capillary column (0.32 mm × 50 m). The detailed calculation procedure of CO conversion and the selectivities to products can be found in a previous paper [33], and the carbon balance was confirmed be better than 95%. The identification and quantification of aromatics in the condensate was completed by using GC analysis of standard aromatic compounds as well as GC-Mass analysis of a real product (the detail can be found in Fig. S1 and Table S1). After reaction, the spent catalyst sample was carefully cooled down to room temperature and then collected. The spent HZSM-5 zeolite sample can be easily separated from magnetic Fe species and quartz sand by sieving the smaller-sized sand first and then using a magnet to attract the Fe species. The recovery for HZSM-5 zeolite was confirmed to be greater than 98%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalyst sample Fig. 1 compares the XRD patterns of fresh HZSM-5, metal-modified HZSM-5 zeolites and all Fe-based catalyst samples. While all HZSM-5 zeolites showed their typical diffraction pattern (JCPDS 44-0003) of peaks located at 7.9°, 8.8°, 8.9°, 23.1°, 23.2°, 23.7° and 24.4°, the HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) did not show the similar crystallinity with other zeolite samples probably due to its high Al concentration for causing a relatively poor thermal stability of zeolite [37]. For all metal-modified HZSM-5 samples, no peaks typing the diffraction patterns of metals or metal oxides were observed in their XRD patterns, which suggested that the impregnated metal species might be highly dispersed on zeolites. For synthesized 96Fe4Mn, 99.2Fe0.8K and 100Fe catalyst samples, only α-Fe2O3 phase (JCPDS 33-0664) was observed at 24.1°, 33.2°, 35.6°, 48.1°, 53.9°, 57.6° and 62.6° after their calcination, while for 10Fe/TiO2 catalyst no peaks for Fe species could be easily observed probably due to its high dispersion on the anatase-TiO2 (JCPDS 04-0477) support. In most cases, various primary Fe oxide phases had been tested for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and, however, the activity and selectivity to hydrocarbon mainly depend on the phase of their carburized products [38,39]. The acidity, especially for the Brønsted acid sites, is much crucial for formation of aromatics in many aromatization reaction systems, for example, the methane-to-benzene reaction over Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst [40] and the methanol-to-aromatics reaction over HZSM-5 zeolite [8]. Fig. 2 compares the NH3-TPD profiles of HZSM-5 zeolites and Ga, Zn, Cu, and Zr-modified HZSM-5 zeolite samples. Two typical NH3 desorption peaks centered at 450–520 and 760–800 K were observed in all profiles of HZSM-5 zeolites, which can reflect the adsorption of NH3 molecules on weak and strong acid sites in zeolite, respectively. Mostly, the two peaks are also related to desorption of NH3 from Lewis and Brønsted (bridged AlOHSi groups) acid sites, respectively [41,42]. Accordingly, Gaussian peak-fitting of these NH3-TPD profiles into two main regions assigned for weak or Lewis acid sites (350–660 K) and strong or Brønsted acid sites (660–900 K), respectively, was conducted to estimate their acidities as shown in Table 1 for various samples. Clearly, the acidity in both weak and strong acid was decreased as expected with increasing the Si/Al ratio, i.e., decreasing the Al concentration in zeolite. For HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 40) and HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 150) zeolites, the strong acidities were only 21% and 2% of that in the HZSM-5 zeolite with Si/Al ratio of 12.5, implying a possibly low activity for aromatic formation. Introduction of 2 wt% Cu, Zn, Ga and Zr into HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) zeolite caused the amount of strong acid to decrease to a certain level, suggesting that the impregnated metal might enter into zeolite channels and anchor on Brønsted acid sites. For Ga modified zeolites, especially, not only the Brønsted acidity but also the weak Lewis acidity decreased obviously. Table 1 also lists the microporosity of HZSM-5 zeolites and metal-modified HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5). The BET surface areas and micropore volumes of HZSM-5 zeolites with different Si/Al ratios fell into reasonable ranges of 320–350 m2/g and 0.1–0.13 cm3/g, respectively. For HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) zeolite, introduction of Ga, Zr, Cu and Zn into the zeolite decreased its BET surface area from 350 m2/g to 320–340 m2/g and micropore volume from 0.127 cm3/g to 0.118–0.121 cm3/g due to diffusion of the impregnated metal into zeolite channels. In addition, the BET surface area and total pore volume of the 96Fe4Mn catalyst sample were confirmed to be 38 m2/g and 0.223 cm3/g, respectively. Fig. 3 shows the H2-TPR profiles of all fresh Fe-based catalyst samples. For 100Fe catalyst sample (α-Fe2O3), three H2-consumption peaks or stages which centered at 647 K, 895 K and the temperature larger than 1170 K were observed for the typical reduction process of α-Fe2O3: Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → FeO → Fe [33]. The obtained H2-TPR profile of α-Fe2O3 might be different in references because it could be influenced by the sample weight, H2 concentration and the essential factor of the ratio of H2 and H2O (externally added or in-situ formed) [43]. Introduction of K or Mn promoter into catalyst could promote the reduction processes of Fe3O4 → FeO and FeO → Fe, especially for the latter. However, the Mn additive slightly suppress the reduction of Fe2O3 into Fe3O4 phase in which reduction peak shifted from 647 K to 661 K but turned to be sharp, while the K additive caused a sharp shoulder peak centered at 580 K in the reduction of K-doped Fe catalysts sample. It is not clear for appearance of this shoulder peak. For 10Fe/TiO2 catalyst sample, although the Fe loading is low, the similar reduction process can be still observed. For the present study, prior to introduction of syngas (CO/H2) into reactor for catalyst carburization, the Fe phase should be a mixture of FeO and Fe3O4 according to the H2-TPR profiles since all Fe-based catalysts were pre-reduced at 723 K for 3 h in tests. 3.2 Catalytic conversion of syngas toward aromatics It is clear that over Fe-based catalyst without addition of HZSM-5 zeolite, typical products for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis including olefins and paraffins were obtained and none of aromatic formations was detected in C5+ hydrocarbons (Fig. S1(b)). By comparison, addition of HZSM-5 zeolite particles into Fe-based catalyst bed could promote a large amount of aromatic formations which include mainly toluene, ethyl-benzene, xylene, ethyl-methyl-benzene and naphthalene in the liquid hydrocarbons (C5+) while little olefins remained, confirming that the olefins should be the primary product for aromatic formations. For example, over the FeMn-HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) hybrid catalyst system, the selectivity to C2–C4 olefins was only 0.2% (CO2-free), while the total aromatic content in C5+ hydrocarbon (selectivity of 24.8%) was greater than 93% which is constituted by 9.2% of benzene, 30.2% of toluene, 5.7% of ethyl-benzene, 27% of xylene, 15.6% of 3C-branced alkylbenzenes, 5.5% of 4C-branced alkylbenzenes and 6.8% of naphthalene and its derivative (Table S2 and S3). In addition, almost for all zeolite-containing tests, the non-aromatic formations in the C5+ liquid phase and most of butane in gas phase were confirmed to be iso-paraffins mainly. Considering the complicated reaction route for conversion syngas toward aromatics, the aromatic content and distribution in C5+ could be greatly influenced by reaction condition and catalyst combination, such as the Si/Al ratio of HZSM-5, reaction temperature and the kind of Fe-based catalyst. Therefore, it highly needs to clarify their effects on the aromatic hydrocarbons synthesis first for further flexible controlling of the aromatic formation and distribution. 3.2.1 Effect of Si/Al ratio on the aromatic hydrocarbons synthesis Fig. 4 shows the effect of Si/Al ratio of HZSM-5 zeolite on CO conversion and average CH distribution in both total hydrocarbon and total aromatics obtained over FeMn-HZSM-5 hybrid catalyst systems at 623 K, 1.5 MPa, 4440 mL/g/h and a H2/CO ratio of 1.0, and the detailed data were also listed in Table S2 and S3. Fig. 5 shows the time-dependences of CO2-free selectivities to CH4, C2–C4 olefins, C2–C4 paraffin and C5+. In most cases similar to those shown in Fig. 5, the selectivities to products were much stable in the last 6 h of a 10 h test, and therefore, unless otherwise indicated, their average values in this period were evaluated for comparison here and in the following sections. For all FeMn-HZSM-5 hybrid catalyst systems, a 2 h induction period in which CO conversion (Fig. 4(a)) and selectivities to CH4 and C2−C4 (Fig. 5) increased rapidly was observed and this is certainly due to the common transformation of Fe or/and Fe oxides into active Fe carbides for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [44]. Except the FeMn-HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) hybrid catalyst, the other catalyst systems showed a similar evolution of CO conversion with FeMn catalyst: CO conversion reached its maximum value of about 83% at 2–3 h of time-on-stream, followed by a decrease but soon afterwards a gradual increase again. This phenomenon might be related with the high reaction temperature (623 K) as compared with the cases at 593 K. At high temperature, serious coking could take place on Fe carbides and lower its activity for activating CO; on the other hand, however, more unreduced Fe species (Fig. 3) might be gradually reduced and carburized in the FTS to supply more active sites. Nevertheless, the selectivities to CH4, C2–C4 olefins, C2–C4 paraffin and C5+ were relatively stable during the last 6 h of whole reaction (Fig. 5). For FeMn-HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) hybrid catalyst, CO conversion was observed to be much stable during test period not including the induction period, probably due to the high Brønsted acidity of the HZSM-5 zeolite for timely converting of formed olefins or/and paraffins into aromatics, not into coke. As FeMn catalyst combined with HZSM-5 zeolite physically, as shown in Fig. 5, the selectivity to light olefins decreased to zero almost while the selectivity to light paraffins increased obviously, suggesting that the light olefins rather than light paraffins should be the primary FT products for aromatic synthesis. With decreasing the Al concentration in HZSM-5, i.e. increasing the Si/Al ratio of zeolite from 12.5 to 150, a small part of light olefins would not be consumed and the increase in the selectivity to light paraffins was reduced. This observation confirms that the Brønsted acidity of HZSM-5 zeolite is the crucial factor of aromatization reaction. As shown in Table S2, with increasing the Si/Al ratio from 12.5 (0.412 mol-NH3/g-cat for Brønsted acidity) to 150 (0.008 mol-NH3/g-cat for Brønsted acidity), the aromatic content in C5+ fraction largely decreased from about 93.7 to 47.3%, although the selectivity to total C5+ (i-C5+ plus aromatics) increased from 25.6% to 40.3% which was mainly contributed by formation of iso-paraffins. For carbon balance, in turn, the selectivity to C2–C4 paraffins decreased and that to C2–C4 olefins slightly increased while the selectivities to CH4 and CO2 were almost unchanged. On the other hand, the average CO conversion increased with lowering the Si/Al ratio from 40 to 12.5 (Fig. 4(b)). However, after carefully comparing and further calculating the data listed in Table S2, it is interestingly observed that the average yields of aromatic (CO2 considered) are almost same which fall into a much narrowed range of 10.4–11.0% over FeMn-HZSM-5 catalyst systems except the FeMn-HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 150) catalyst system. For the latter, however, the yield is about only 7.6%. There results strongly suggests the Brønsted acidity of HZSM-5 not only plays an important role in the formation of aromatics but also influence the CO conversion over FeMn catalyst. For FeMn-HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 150), especially, the remaining hydrocarbons (52.7%) in C5+ liquid phase were mainly iso-paraffins with a small amount of cycloparaffins and paraffins, as shown in Fig. S2. Further, the Si/Al ratio of HZSM-5 zeolite also had influence on the distribution of aromatic hydrocarbons. As shown in Fig. 4(b) as well as in Table S3, the evolution of the content of each aromatic fraction was not obvious and even irregular when the Si/Al ratio increased from 12.5 to 25 probably due to similar Brønsted acidity in those zeolites (Fig. 2(a) and Table 1); however, as the Si/Al ratio further increased to 40 and then 150, the contents of benzene, toluene, naphthalene and its derivatives decreased visibly while that of total 3C-branced benzene derivatives mainly including 1-ethyl-2-methyl-benzne and 1,3,5-trimethyl-benzene largely increased in reverse. For xylene, by comparison, the Si/Al ratio showed slight influence on its content it in total aromatic hydrocarbons even in the case of HZSM-5 with the ratio of 150; over the same zeolite, the naphthalene and its derivative were almost completely suppressed. Combination of distributions of hydrocarbons and detailed aromatic fractions varied with Si/Al ratio of HZSM-5 zeolite could reveal a primary reaction route for conversion of syngas into aromatics. 3.2.2 Effects of reaction temperature, pressure, space velocity and H2/CO ratio on the aromatic hydrocarbons synthesis In this and the following sections, the FeMn-HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) hybrid catalyst system was mainly used for tests. Table 2 and 3 show the effects of reaction temperature (553–623 K), pressure (0.2–3.0 MPa), and space velocity (2220–8880 mL/g/h) and H2/CO ratio (0.5–2.0) on the average CO conversion and CH distribution in total hydrocarbon and total aromatics, respectively. The data were also plotted with bar charts as shown in Fig. S3 in which the profiles of time-dependence of CO conversion were also given. Increasing reaction temperature resulted in an expected linear increase in CO conversion as well as the selectivity to CO2 [33]. Over the hybrid catalyst, the selectivities to i-C5+ and aromatic hydrocarbons obviously decreased from 22.3% to only 1.6% and from 39.4% to 24.0%, respectively, while the aromatic content in the C5+ hydrocarbons increased in reverse from 63.9% to 93.7% with elevating temperature from 553 K to 623 K. Accompanying with the decrease in the selectivity to total C5+, the selectivities to CH4 and C2–C4 paraffins increased remarkably (Table 2 and Fig. S3(b)) due to serious cracking of C5+ at high temperature over HZSM-5 naturally. It should be noted that at the lowest temperature of 553 K, the selectivity to C2–C4 olefins gradually increased after 4 h of reaction (Fig. S4(a)), resulting in a higher average C2–C4 olefins’ selectivity (5.4%) than those obtained at higher temperatures (Table 2). While the CO conversion was observed to be stable during the whole reaction period, the increase in the selectivity to C2–C4 olefins must suggest the deactivation of HZSM-5 zeolite for further conversion of olefins into aromatics. Fig. S4(b) confirms that the liquid hydrocarbons did contain a certain amount of non-aromatic products which were iso-paraffins mainly. The reaction temperature could also affect the aromatic distribution obviously. The results as shown in Table 3 as well as Fig. S3(b) suggests that formation of heavy aromatics including 3C- and 4C-branced alkylbenzenes were favored at low temperatures, in comparison with formation of light aromatics (benzene and toluene) and even naphthalene and its derivatives. For example, at 553 K the contents of 3C- and 4C-branched alkylbenzenes reached 33.1% and 9.1%, but would remarkably decrease by 52.9% and 39.6% to only 15.6% and 5.5%, respectively, as temperature increased to 623 K; Instead, the contents of benzene, toluene, naphthalene and its derivatives could increase by 1–4 times by raising the temperature from 553 to 623 K. For xylene, its content also decreased with increasing temperature but only 5.7 percentage point were lost (from 32.7% to 27%) which is great lower than the value of 17.5 percentage points for 3C-branched benzene derivative, while for ethyl-benzene the increasing of temperature seemed to show little influence on it content in total aromatics. Similar to reaction temperature, increasing reaction pressure is also beneficial to increase CO conversion since obtaining of a high CO conversion for FTS reaction over Fe-based catalysts is suggested to be conducted at a high reaction temperature and a high pressure [33]. With the level of CO conversion increasing from 6.7% at 0.2 MPa to 86.7% at 3.0 MPa, the selectivity to CO2 by reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) also increased from 26.3% to about 44%. By increasing reaction pressure, the selectivities to CH4 and C2–C4 decreased but the selectivity to iso-C5+ increased obviously. For n-C2°–C4° and i-C4° formations, however, their selectivities went through their maxima at 1.5 MPa while for aromatic formation, its selectivity irregularly changed within a narrowed range of 34–40%. As a result, the aromatic content in total C5+ greatly decreased with the increase in reaction pressure. Especially at 3.0 MPa, as shown in Fig. S5(b), more iso-paraffins were detected in liquid hydrocarbons, apparently suggesting higher pressure might promote hydrogenation and isomerization of olefins and relatively weaken the aromatization of them over HZSM-5 zeolite. At the lowest reaction pressure of 0.2 MPa, although the aromatic content in C5+ was the highest, being 98.5% with little iso-paraffins (Fig. S5(a)), it should be noted that the selectivity to C2–C4 olefins was high as much as 12.3% at the lowest CO conversion of 6.7%. Here such high selectivity to C2–C4 olefins was not due to the deactivation of HZSM-5 similar to the case at 553 K, but possibly because of a low probability of olefins entering zeolite channels at low pressures. For aromatic distribution in C5+, it is clear from Table 3 as well as Fig. S3(d) that still the toluene, xylene and 3C-branced benzene derivatives were the main products in aromatic hydrocarbons. With increasing reaction pressure from 0.2 MPa to 2.5 MPa (except 3.0 MPa), the fractions of benzene, toluene and ethyl-benzene increased continuously, while the fractions of 3C-branched alkylbenzene, naphthalene and its derivatives decreased in reverse. It is worth pointing out that the highest fraction of naphthalene and its derivatives appeared together with the highest content of 3C-branced alkylbenzene (0.2 MPa), which is different from the case at 553 K. Moreover, in the course of raising reaction pressure the evolutions of the naphthalene and its derivatives’ contents were consistent to that of 3C-branced benzene derivatives; on the contrary, the evolutions of the former were totally against that of the latter in the course of increasing reaction temperature (Table 3). In addition, the evolutions of CO conversion with time on stream at different reaction pressures (Fig. S3(c)) suggested that the induction period of Fe-based catalyst could be largely shortened at low pressure for the maximum CO conversion appeared at the first point. A low pressure also suggests a low partial pressure of H2 on the surface of the reduced Fe phase, which would greatly reduce in suppressing the dissociation of CO on the surface and subsequent carburization of Fe species. Probably due to the same reason, the carbon deposition took place on the active Fe phase more easily at lower pressures, which in turn lowered the activity of Fe-based catalyst in a few hours. By comparison, CO conversion shows much stable after reaching of its maximum at the high pressures. With increasing the flow rate of syngas, i.e., increasing the space velocity, the CO conversion certainly decreased, and the CO2-free selectivity to C2–C4 olefins also increased as expected, suggesting that the formed olefins could not be transformed into aromatics timely and fully. However, the elevated C2–C4 olefins selectivity did not indicate the deactivation of HZSM-5 zeolite and therefore the aromatic content in C5+ maintained a high level greater than 90%. Considering for the aromatic distribution, no great variation was observed as the space velocity ranged from 2220 to 8880 mL/g/h. By comparison, increasing the ratio of H2 and CO not only influenced the CO conversion but also changed the hydrocarbon distribution obviously over the FeMn-HZSM-5 hybrid catalyst system. The CO conversion largely increased from 39.9% to 76.9% with the ratio increasing from 0.5 to 2, which in line with similar observations in Fe-based FTS [45]. In addition, because of high partial pressure of H2, the selectivity to CO2 from water gas reaction (WGS, CO + H2O = CO2 + H2) suppressed and the hydrogenation possibility over active sites enhanced. As a result, the CO2-free selectivities to CH4 (30.2%) and C2–C4 paraffins (58.6%) turned to be extremely high at the H2/CO ratio of 2, and in turn the selectivity to C5+ had to be much low, being only 9.6%. Nevertheless, the aromatic content in the C5+ was almost close to 100% as shown in Table 3. Furthermore, at the high H2/CO ratio, the fraction of heavy aromatics (A9+) was observed to be 56.9% which is greater than those obtained at the ratios of 0.5 (36.3%) and 1 (36.8%), while the fractions of benzene, toluene and ethylbenzene were correspondingly decreased. The reason for this phenomenon might be that the formed light aromatics could be hydrogenated more easily at high H2 partial pressure than the heavy aromatics [46]. 3.2.3 Effect of catalyst combinations on the aromatic hydrocarbons synthesis Both Fe-based catalyst for FTS and HZSM-5-based zeolite for aromatization of hydrocarbons are crucial to direct synthesis of aromatics from syngas in this study. Table 4 and 5 show the effects of weight ratio of HZSM-5 and FeMn (0.5–5), metal modification of HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) and the kind of Fe-based catalyst on the average CO conversion and CH distributions in total hydrocarbons and aromatic fraction in total aromatics, respectively. Again, all data were plotted visually with bar charts as shown in Fig. S6 in which the profiles of time-dependence of CO conversion were also given. Note that the weight of FeMn catalyst charged in the bed was fixed to be 0.5 g. Clearly, excessive loading of HZSM-5 zeolite in catalytic bed did not promote the conversion of syngas into aromatics, but on the contrary, could extremely suppress the conversion of CO into any hydrocarbons. As shown in Table 4 as well as in Fig. S6, the average CO conversion reached 81.9% at a HZSM-5 and FeMn weight ratio of 0.5, while it largely decreased with increasing the ratio and even to only 2% at the ratio of 5. HZSM-5 zeolite plays the key role in aromatization of alkanes and alkenes formed in FTS. However, the obtained experimental results suggested that the excess acid sites that surround the FeMn particles might have suppressed the carburization of Fe or/and Fe oxide phases, and therefore influence the activation and conversion of CO and H2 into CH x groups and further their chain growth. One observable experimental phenomenon suggesting that Fe might still be a reduced phase after 10 h reaction is that the spontaneous combustion of FeMn spent sample took place immediately as long as the sample was poured out from reactor and exposed to air, especially in the cases of HZSM-5 and FeMn weight ratios of 2 and 5. On the other hand, in the Fe-based FTS reaction, basic promoters such as K and Na was generally considered to be beneficial to adsorption and dissociation of CO over Fe carbides due to their electron-donating property [47–49]. By comparison, acidic environment of zeolite should be a serious inhibitor for CO dissociation. Nevertheless, the hydrocarbon distribution changed little and the aromatic content in the C5+ liquid phase even slightly increased from 91% to 97% with increasing the ratio. As to the evolution of aromatic formations with increasing the weight ratio, it can be observed from Table 5 that excessive loading of the HZSM-5 zeolite decreased the contents of light aromatics like benzene, toluene and xylene, but increased that of the heavy aromatics and especially the polyaromatics like naphthalene and its derivations clearly, i.e., driving the light aromatics toward heavy and polycyclic aromatics. This should be related with the further dehydrogenation and cyclization of benzene and alkyl-benzene into polyaromatics over the excessive Brønsted acid sites in the HZSM-5 zeolite. It can be easily observed from all above tests that the aromatics formed over the FeMn-HZSM-5 hybrid catalyst system comprised a certain amount of highly branched alkylbenzenes like 3C and 4C-branched alkylbenzenes and alkyl-naphthalenes which have low additional values compared with benzene, toluene and xylene (BTX) in chemical market. Doping of some selected metals including Cu, Zn, Ga and Zr into HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) was expected to examine their effects on the distribution of aromatic formations in the C5+ liquid phase by adjusting the Brønsted acidity in zeolite or/and providing special active sites for promoting dehydrogenation of formed alkanes, such as Ga and Zn [50,51]. The four tests were compared with the test over FeMn and metal-free HZSM-5 hybrid catalyst system at the condition of 593 K, 1.0 MPa, 2220 mL/g/h and FeMn-HZSM-5 wt ratio of 1. As shown in Table 4, over the FeMn and Cu-modified HZSM-5 catalyst system, the CO conversion was observed to decrease obviously from 69.9% to 48.3%, while doping of Ga or Zr metal into the HZSM-5 increased both CO conversion and aromatic content in C5+ liquid phase. Addition of Zn metal showed a slight decrease in CO conversion and a slight increase in aromatic content. However, over the Ga- and Zr-modified HZSM-5 catalyst systems, both the selectivity to CO2 and the contents of CH4 and C2–C4 paraffins in total hydrocarbons increased, which results in an obvious decrease in the CO2-free selectivity to C5+ from 34.7% to only 27–29%. The doped Ga and Zr species in zeolite might be more active for hydrogenation of part of olefins into light paraffins [52]. As a result, a lower H2 partial pressure around these metals could shift the WGS reaction (CO + H2O = CO2 + H2) right to increase the CO2 formation. However, as shown in Table 5, the addition of the selected metals did not change the distribution of hydrocarbons dramatically at test condition. For Zr-modified HZSM-5, especially, the fraction of 3C-branched alkylbenzenes decreased while that of toluene increased. However, we believe that the modification of zeolite’s surface acidity or addition of special active sites in zeolite using pertinent strategies should work in increasing aromatic content in total hydrocarbons and regulating the distribution of aromatics, which is similar with the methanol-to-aromatic process [53,54]. Besides, different FTS catalysts determine varied distribution of olefins and paraffin from syngas, which might directly influence the content and distribution of aromatic formations. Here we investigated a bulk Fe catalyst (100Fe), a K-promoted Fe catalyst (99.2Fe0.8K) and a TiO2-supported 10%Fe/TiO2 catalyst which showed different FTS performance compared with FeMn catalyst, for studying their catalytic behaviors in the aromatic synthesis as they composited with the HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) zeolite. The obtained catalytic results were shown in Tables 4 and 5 as well as in Fig. S4(e) and (f). Over the bulk 100Fe catalyst, the average CO conversion was only 39.5% with a CO2 selectivity of 38.3% while over the K-promoted 99.2Fe0.8K catalyst the CO conversion largely increased to 94.1% which can be owed to the K-facilitated CO dissociation [47]. Over the two catalysts, the distributions of hydrocarbons were also quite different. The bulk 100Fe catalyst showed both higher selectivities to C2–C4 light olefins (23.9%, CO2-free) and light paraffins (34.1%, 18.8% for CH4 and 15.3% for C2–C4) than the 99.2Fe0.8K catalyst. As a result, the olefin and paraffin ratio, O/P, (C2–C4, 1.6), and C5+ selectivity (42.0%) were both lower than those over the latter catalyst which were 4.6 and 75.4%, respectively. What is more, as shown in Fig. S7(a), for the 100Fe catalyst, the obtained C5+ liquid hydrocarbons also contained a large amount of saturated paraffins with a low O/P ratio of 0.92, while for the 99.2Fe0.8K catalyst, α-olefins were the main product with the O/P ratio of 4.3 (Fig. S7(b)). For the supported 10Fe/TiO2 catalyst, the CO conversion reached 68.6% with a CO2 selectivity of 47%; however, other than 19.8% of C2–C4 light olefins (CO2-free), the remaining hydrocarbons including C5+ formation (Fig. S7(c)) were almost n-paraffins. The three Fe-based FTS catalysts respectively mixed with HZSM-5 zeolite at a weight ratio of 1 were tested at the same condition. Interestingly, the bulk 100Fe and HZSM-5 hybrid catalyst system further increased the CO conversion to 67.3% and the 99.2Fe0.8K and HZSM-5 catalyst system maintained the CO conversion at the high level over 94% as expected, but the 10%Fe/TiO2 and HZSM-5 catalyst system almost suppressed the conversion of CO (only 2.6%) into any hydrocarbons, not mentioning the aromatics. For this repeated and confirmed phenomenon the reason is not clear presently, probably related to the difficult carburization of Fe or/and Fe oxides clusters on the TiO2 support surrounded by acidic HZSM-5 zeolite particles. It can be seen from Table 4 that about 90% of C5+ liquid phase (34.5%, CO2-free selectivity) was aromatics after a 10-h test over the 100Fe-HZSM-5 catalyst system, while the value obtained over 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 catalyst system was much smaller, being only 46.9%, although the selectivity to total C5+ was higher to be 72.9%. After carefully comparing the selectivity to C2–C4 olefin and its time-dependence profiles (Fig. S8(a)), the average C2–C4 olefin selectivity (6.4%) over the 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 catalyst system was clearly higher than that (1.2%) over the 100Fe-HZSM-5 catalyst system; on the other hand, over the former catalyst system the high selectivity to C2–C4 olefin should be due to its gradual increase after a 4 h reaction, which suggests that the formed olefins could not be fully transformed into aromatics over the HZSM-5 zeolite and that the zeolite had deactivated probably due to coking. We further performed an only 4 h test over the 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 catalyst system, and aromatic content in C5+ did increase to 75.5% but was still less than that (larger than 90%) obtained over FeMn-HZSM-5 catalyst system. Interestingly, during initial 4 h period, the CO2-free selectivity to aromatic was the highest (53.8%) among all tests and that to n-C2–C4 paraffins greatly suppressed. The non-aromatic hydrocarbons in C5+ were confirmed to be also iso-paraffins, not the unreacted olefins or n-paraffins, as shown in Fig. S8(c). These results apparently showed that the low aromatic content in C5+ was ascribed to more iso-paraffins formed in the reaction; however, the results might actually reveal the different conditions needed for isomerization and aromatization over HZSM-5 zeolite. The K-promoted Fe catalyst benefits olefin formation with a high O/P ratio [33], while the high olefin formation rate could also lead a high coke formation rate on Brønsted acid sites, which certainly weakens their activity for aromatization of olefins but turns to the isomerization that is independent of the Brønsted acidity [55]. Also interestingly, although the olefin and paraffin distributions were much different over HZSM-5-free catalysts, the aromatic distribution in total aromatic hydrocarbons had no great difference among FeMn-HZSM-5, 100Fe-HZSM-5 and 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 catalyst systems. However, the fraction of naphthalene and its derivatives (5.1% in total) was low for 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 catalyst system, compared with the other two catalyst systems. Moreover, over the catalyst system, this fraction was lower in the initial reaction period (about only 2.6% in the beginning 4 h test), and the fraction increased with increasing time on stream. Comparing the data obtained in 4 h and 10 h tests for 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 catalyst system indicates that heavy aromatics (A9+) might preferentially form as HZSM-5 zeolite deactivated, resulting in a clear increase in the fraction of A9+ aromatics. 3.3 Discussion Based on above results from a large number of experiments, the syngas (CO + H2) can be directly converted into aromatic-containing hydrocarbons over Fe-based FTS catalysts and HZSM-5 zeolite hybrid catalyst systems. It is worth noting that the aromatic formations are highly rich in the liquid C5+ phase and their content can be reached over 95%, and the gaseous products were mainly CH4 and C2–C4 paraffins and a small amount of C2–C4 olefins, which can be used to be the component of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) for fuel or further aromatization [56–58]. Moreover, the number of substituent group of CH3 in main aromatic products is not larger than 3. As shown in Scheme 1 , CO and H2 molecules adsorbed and were activated over Fe carbide active sites firstly, followed by in situ formation of CH2 radical and its chain growth into C n H2 n olefins or/and further hydrogenation of part of CH2 and olefins into CH4 and C n H2 n +2, respectively; the formed olefins and paraffins would be converted into aromatics or/and iso-paraffins via hydrocracking, hydroisomerization, oligomerization, cyclization, and H transfer over acidic HZSM-5 zeolite depending on reaction conditions. Clearly, the synthesis of aromatic from syngas over the hybrid catalyst system seems to be much complicated, considering for CO conversion, selectivity to aromatic, aromatic distribution and catalyst deactivation, which would be discussed in detail in following sections. 3.3.1 CO conversion Besides the basic thermodynamic and kinetic factors including reaction temperature, pressure, space velocity and the ratio of H2/CO, the CO conversion essentially depends on the Fe-based FTS catalysts in the synthesis of aromatics from syngas. Commonly, the kind of Fe catalyst (preparation method, promoter, support, Fe loading and their morphology, etc.) and its reduction and carburization (the phase of Fe carbide and especially, its crystal facet) could directly influence the activation of CO and H2 and further products’ formation [33]. For the hybrid catalysts used in the conversion of CO into aromatics, the presence of HZSM-5 zeolite could promote the CO conversion but also suppress it. In nature, timely transformation of olefins or/and paraffins formed on Fe-based catalysts into other products over HZSM-5 zeolite can drive the further conversion of CO in thermodynamics, which can be also observed in many comparable reactions [59,31]. For example, the addition of HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) zeolite into FeMn and 100Fe catalyst beds caused CO conversion to both increase obviously, compared with the cases of zeolite-free catalytic bed. However, excess loading of HZSM-5 zeolite into FeMn beds or addition of the zeolite into 10Fe/TiO2 catalyst bed leaded CO conversion largely to decrease. For the former case, we have inferred that the reduced Fe species was not easy to be carburized in an acid atmosphere and therefore formation and chain growth of CH2 groups were suppressed. To confirm this, an additional test in which FeMn catalyst was previously carburized well and then mixed with HZSM-5 zeolite at the HZSM-5/FeMn weight ratio of 2 and some H2-TPR experiments were carried out. The obtained catalytic performance was shown in Fig. 6 while H2-TPR profiles were shown in Fig. 7 . It is clear that addition of HZSM-5 zeolite into FeMn catalyst particles at a weight ratio of either 0.5 or 2 did not influence the reduction of FeMn catalyst below the temperature of 723 K obviously and even promoted the catalyst reduction at high temperature region (723–973 K), which suggests that the FeMn catalyst should have same reduction degree at the employed temperature of 723 K for all tests. However, as well-carburized FeMn catalyst particles and two-fold amount of zeolite were charged into reactor bed, the CO conversion (Fig. 6) did increase from 12.1% to 38.9% but still not reach the expected value of 69.9% that obtained in the case of FeMn-HZSM-5 wt ratio of 1. Together with above observations, therefore, the most possible justification should be that the excess acidic environment suppressed the adsorption of CO on Fe carbides and, especially, the reduced Fe species, let alone the following dissociation of CO and further formation and chain growth of CH2 radicals. If this is the case, the much low CO conversion of only 2.6% obtained over 10%Fe/TiO2-HZSM-5 (weight ratio = 1) catalyst system can be ascribed to the actual weight ratio of HZSM-5 and Fe oxides on TiO2 which should be extremely high over 5:1. 3.3.2 Catalyst deactivation Commonly, Fe-based FTS catalysts have long lifetime for conversion of syngas into either olefins or paraffins [60,61]. For the present hybrid catalyst systems, the cause for the obvious rising in olefins formation rate but little influence on CO conversion (as shown in Tables 2 and 4 and Figs. S4(a) and S8(a)) in the reaction should be certainly ascribed to the deactivation of the HZSM-5 zeolite and blocking of zeolite channels by coke deposition should be responsible for the deactivation firstly. Therefore, TG analysis of most spent zeolite samples were conducted for measurement of coke amount in spent sample. The obtained weight loss profiles were shown in Fig. 8 and coke amounts evaluated between 673 and 1173 K were listed in each figure. For all profiles, the weight loss between 300 and 450 K could be ascribed to desorption of the physically adsorbed water on spent sample. For the tests conducted at low reaction temperatures (573 K and 593 K) and over 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 catalyst system in which the selectivity to olefins gradually increased after a few hours of reaction, the coke amount in these collected spent zeolite samples were obviously larger than 0.06 g-coke/g-cat. Especially, the spent zeolite separated from 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 catalyst system showed the highest coke amount of 0.109 g-coke/g-cat after the 10 h reaction. Further measurement of the N2 absorption and desorption isotherms of some spent zeolites (Fig. 9 ) showed that only 6.5 m2/g of BET surface area and 0.001 cm3/g of micropore volume (Table 6 ) remained in the spent zeolite recovered from FeK-HZSM-5. Over 98% loss in both BET surface area and micropore volume highly suggested the coke mainly formed in the zeolite channels where the aromatization reaction took place. Such observation can be also found in many HZSM-5 zeolite-involved reactions, as coke amount in spent sample reached 0.10–0.15 g-coke/g-cat [62]. Similarly, the BET surface areas and micropore volumes of spent zeolites recovered from FeMn-HZSM-5 catalyst systems under 3.0 MPa (0.074 g-coke/g-cat, coke amount) were also low, being 37.6 m2/g and 0.016 cm3/g, respectively, while the values for the spent sample recovered under 593 K which contained about 0.038 g-coke/g-cat of coke amount were 228 m2/g and 0.086 cm3/g, respectively. Low reaction temperature is not beneficial to aromatization of olefins or/and paraffins over the HZSM-5 zeolite [57], and those formations could polymerize into coke precursors on the Brønsted acid sites, resulting in the deactivation of HZSM-5 zeolite. With increasing the reaction temperature, more small molecules such as CH4 and C2–C4 paraffins would be formed in first FTS step and also aromatization reactions by cracking (see in Table 4). In addition, although the selectivity to C2–C4 olefins did not increase in the reaction with increasing reaction pressure, the coke amount in the spent zeolite increased obviously. Comparing with low pressure, it might be possible that formed olefins and paraffins would be impelled into zeolite channels at high pressure and did not diffused out easily, whereupon the coke had to form in the channels, giving rise to an increase in coke amount. Even so, isomerization of olefins and paraffins over the coked zeolite was not influenced at high pressure. For the 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 catalyst system, especially, serious coking was observed even in the first 4 h of reaction and the coke amount in the recovered HZSM-5 was confirmed to be 0.096 g-coke/g-cat. Extremely high selectivity to olefins in C5+ (Fig. S8(a)) over the 99.2Fe0.8K catalyst should be responsible for the high coking rate on zeolite, while the poisoning of zeolite by K migration from FeK catalyst could be excluded. An additional test in which syngas successively flowed 99.2Fe0.8K catalyst layer and HZSM-5 zeolite layer separated by quartz wool confirmed that still high coke amount of 0.110 g-coke/g-cat in spent zeolite and similar aromatic content and distribution in liquid C5+ phase was observed. Besides, the factors of Si/Al ratio of zeolite, space velocity and metal promoter also showed some little influence on coke formation rate but less significant than those of reaction temperature, pressure and the kind of Fe-based FTS catalyst. H2O and CO2 are the typical products in FTS process as shown in Scheme 1. Mostly, extraction of framework Al in HZSM-5 zeolite could take place in an oxygen-containing atmosphere at high temperatures [63] and this might also be one cause for deactivation of HZSM-5 zeolite in the title reaction. Therefore, a longer test of 45 h was performed over the FeMn-HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) catalyst system at 593 K, 1.0 MPa, 4440 mL/g/h and H2/CO = 1 (the catalytic performance was shown in Fig. S9), and 27Al NMR measurement of the spent HZSM-5 zeolite as well as a fresh one was carried out. Fig. 10 shows the obtained spectrum. In addition, the coke amount in the spent HZSM-5 was confirmed to be 0.060 g-coke/g-cat, and the BET surface area and micropore volume of the sample were 71.0 m2/g and 0.029 cm3/g, respectively. It can be seen that octahedral extra-framework aluminum which is corresponding to the NMR peak at 0 ppm originally exists in the as-received HZSM-5 zeolite, besides the basic tetrahedral framework aluminum for the peak centered at 56 ppm. After 45 h of reaction, the intensity of both peaks weakened and the peak (56 ppm) even broadened. This should be related to coke deposition on Brønsted acid sites [64], i.e., the group of AlOHSi, and the framework Al should be less sensitive to the applied electromagnetic pulses in the measurement. However, integration of the two peaks showed that the ratio of 56 ppm peak to 0 ppm peak did not increase after 45 h (52.7), compared to the ratio (72.8) for fresh sample, suggesting that the dealumination effect was not significant in present study. In fact, the applied reaction temperature less than 623 K is much mild for the HZSM-5 zeolite which is usually of high hydrothermal stability over 773 K. 3.3.3 Selectivity to aromatic formations (content of aromatics in liquid C5+ phase) Scheme 2 shows a schematic route to formation of aromatics and iso-paraffins from FTS hydrocarbon products over the HZSM-5 zeolite. Because of the space limitation of zeolite channels, only the small molecules of C2–C5 hydrocarbons can be well adsorbed in the channels according to an end-to-end adsorption model [65], and further undergoes the cycloaddition reaction into C4–C10 precursors of aromatics in the cross section of zeolite. This is in line with the observation that the total carbon number in an alkylbenzene was indeed not larger than 10 in the study. For the C6+ olefins desorbed over Fe carbides by β-hydride abstraction of a terminally bonded surface alkyl species, they could be catalytically hydrocracked or/and isomerized over Brønsted acid sites into C3–C5 olefins and alkylcarbenium ions and iso-hydrocarbons; on the other hand, the formation of C1°–C4° hydrocarbons over Fe catalyst might not be involved in the following reactions over zeolite, while the heavier saturated n-paraffins (C5+°) could be also hydrocracked or/and isomerized over Lewis acid sites. The latter reactions should be slow because still some n-paraffins were detected in liquid phases (Figs. S2, S4(b) and S5(b)). Based on the widely accepted carbonium mechanism, C2–C5 olefins could polymerize with each other into iso-C4–C10 over Brønsted acid sites, followed by cyclization of these olefin formations into alkyl-cyclohexanes in the zeolite channels, and then multistep H transfer with C2–C4 olefins into alkylbenzenes and C2–C4 paraffins. The formed alkylbenzenes could further polycondensated into alkyl-naphthalenes and even aromatic coke. As zeolite had a high Si/Al ratio, i.e., low Brønsted acidity, or deposited coke formation, on the other hand, the iso-paraffins (C4+) could competitively formed by hydrogenation of iso-C4–C10 carbenium ions. Note that for most zeolite-containing tests the FTS catalysts were the same 96Fe4Mn catalyst and the products in C5+ were mainly aromatics and iso-paraffins. Therefore, the selectivity to aromatic formations and the content of aromatics in the liquid C5+ phase are actually determined by the competition of aromatization and isomerization reactions over different HZSM-5 zeolites under varied reaction conditions. High reaction temperature and high Brønsted acidity (low Si/Al ratio) benefit cracking reaction of higher hydrocarbons as well as dealkylation reaction, which lowers the selectivity to aromatics. Over metal-free HZSM-5 zeolite, H transfer is considered to be accompanied with the formation of aromatics [13], which suggests that an increased selectivity to aromatic should lead an also increased selectivity to light alkanes. However, the results shown in Tables 2 and S2 went against that in the cases of zeolite with low Si/Al ratio and at high reaction temperature, certainly due to the dominant cracking reaction. HZSM-5 zeolite with a high Si/Al ratio is suitable for formation of iso-paraffins, and this is why synthesis of the gasoline-ranged hydrocarbons is usually performed over the HZSM-5 zeolite of high Si/Al ratio (>100) [26]. Carefully comparing the data in Tables 2 and S2, although the selectivity to aromatic decreased with raising reaction temperature (573–623 K) and lowering the Si/Al ratio (12.5–40), the CO conversion showed a reversed trend and the yield of aromatic dropped in a much narrowed range of 10.4–11.8%, as the CO2 selectivity was taken in account. These results suggest that the aromatic formation rate was stable and might be independent with Si/Al ratio and reaction temperature as the conditions varied during a certain range. At low reaction temperature of 553 K, the high selectivity to iso-C5+ can be ascribed to the deactivation of HZSM-5 zeolite (see Fig. S4(a)). Coke deposition on zeolite could lower the Brønsted acidity in zeolite [66], and the coked zeolite might benefit the isomerization reaction and would lower the aromatic content in liquid hydrocarbons. Similar cases can be also observed for the 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) hybrid catalyst system in which the selectivity to i-C5+ was high to 38.7% after 10 h of reaction while the value was only 17.5% after 4 h (Table 4). This results reasonably inferred that the aromatic selectivity and content in C5+ should be much high during very initial reaction period when coke content in zeolite was low. On the other hand, the same justification can be applied for that increasing reaction pressure also resulted in an increased selectivity to iso-paraffins and therefore a decreased aromatic content (Table 2 and Fig. S3(d)), because the coke formation rate increased with increasing reaction pressure as seen in Fig. 8. High H2/CO ratio showed greatly suppression effect in the formations of iso-paraffins and aromatic although it promoted the CO conversion. High H2 partial pressure could promote the hydrogenation of (CH2) n into light paraffins over Fe-based FTS catalysts. Especially, as the ratio reached 2.0, the i-C5+ formation was almost suppressed and its selectivity was only 0.1%, resulting in an extremely high aromatic content in the liquid phase. Increasing both space velocity within 2220–8880 mL/g/h and weight ratio of HZSM-5 and FeMn catalyst showed slight influence on the formations of i-C5+ and aromatics. High space velocity (or superficial velocity) reduced the conversion of formed light olefins into both i-C5+ and aromatic formations and alleviated the cracking reaction. Therefore, the selectivity to C2–C4 olefins was slightly high (2.8%) at 8880 mL/g/h and that to n-C2–C4 paraffins decreased from 31.7% (2220 mL/g/h) to 24.8% (8880 mL/g/h). Doping of metal into HZSM-5 zeolite was expected to increase the activity in catalytic dehydrogenation of formed paraffins and promote their conversion into aromatics. Over the metal-modified HZSM-5 catalysts, the formation mechanism of aromatic was considered to be different from that over pure HZSM-5 zeolite [56]. Without the need of H transfer reaction, the aromatic precursors, i.e., cyclo-paraffins, could be directly dehydrogenated to aromatics over metal active sites [13]. However, limited improvement in reducing the selectivity to paraffins was observed at present reaction conditions. For this aspect, more investigations including suitable reaction condition and catalyst preparation are still needed to decrease the selectivity to light paraffins. 3.3.4 Distribution of aromatic formations In most cases, about 70–90% of aromatics were concentrated on toluene, xylene and 3C-brached alkylbenzenes (mainly ethyl-methyl-benzene). The aromatic distribution was considered to have weak relationship with the kind feedstock of olefins over zeolite, because the rapid cracking and oligomerization reactions were always prior to aromatization reaction. On the other hand, however, the aromatic distribution actually reveals an in-situ distribution of olefins. Supposed that benzene and all alkylbenzenes are primary and not secondary products in the aromatic formation. The light olefins, especially the C3–C5, should be their main precursors (C3 + C4 to toluene, C3 + C5 and C4 + C4 to xylene and C4 + C5 to A9). With increasing the Si/Al ratio of HZSM-5 zeolite (lowering the Brønsted acidity), the activity for cracking as well as dehydrogenation and oligomerization over zeolite would be slowdown. Therefore, the concentrations of in situ formed C4 and C5 should be higher than those in the cases of zeolite having lower Si/Al ratio. As a result, the fraction of 3C-branched alkylbenzenes increased while those of benzene and toluene decreased obviously. Due to the low Brønsted acidity in HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 150), the activity for further polycondensation of alkylbenzene into naphthalene and alkyl-naphthalene also declined, leading to a much low fraction of naphthalene and its derivatives in aromatics. However, at a low Si/Al ratio, the structure of aromatic formation showed more complex [26], for example, alkyl-naphthalenes. Similar observation could be found in the cases of tests at low reaction temperatures. A low reaction temperature certainly suggests a low activity for the hydrocracking as well as polycondensation. Therefore, it can be seen (Table 3) that the fractions of 3C- and 4C-bracnched alkylbenzenes were clearly higher at 553 K than those at 623 K, and the fractions of benzene, toluene and naphthalene were low. Also, the dealkylnation of 3C- and 4C-branched alkylbenzenes should be taken account for their low fractions at high temperature. Although the intrinsic selectivity to olefins in C5+ (see Fig. S7(b)) was greatly high over the base 99.2Fe0.8K catalyst, the aromatic distribution obtained over hybrid FeMn-HZSM-5 catalyst system was much similar to that in most cases. This result suggests that these formed heavy olefins had been fully cracked into light olefins over acidic HZSM-5 zeolite prior to aromatization. Heavier aromatics including multi-alkyl benzenes and naphthalenes are supposed to be formed on external acid sites of zeolite or very near the pore mouths of channels, because of their larger kinetic diameter than the pore size. For example, with increasing the HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) weight in catalytic bed (Table 5 and Fig. S6(b)), the fractions of 4C-branched alkylbenzenes, naphthalene and alkylnaphthalenes increased obviously on the trend while those of light aromatics (A6–A8) decreased. This should be certainly ascribed to the secondary transformation of light aromatics toward heavy aromatics on the more external acid sites. Similar case can be observed at low reaction pressure (Table 3 and Fig. S3(d)). At low pressure, formed light aromatics easily diffused out the zeolite channels and relatively low H2 partial pressure promoted their further polycondensation into naphthalene and its derivatives. Doping of SiO2 onto the external surface of zeolite [8,67] by silylanization, chemical vapor deposition (CVD) or chemical liquid deposition (CLD), and creating of mesopore in zeolite [68] are optional ways to tune the aromatic distribution via decreasing the external acid sites and enhancing the products’ diffusivity. 3.3.5 The selectivities to CH4 and CO2 formations It is observed that the selectivity to CH4 increased obviously as HZSM-5 zeolite mixed with FeMn catalyst (Table S2 and Table 4). No doubt, the most of CH4 is mainly formed over FeMn catalyst in the FTS reaction via hydrogenation of metal-CH2 groups (Scheme 1), while the increase in the CH4 selectivity could come from three aspects. 1) Hydrocarbons could be cracked into short-chain hydrocarbons including CH4 over strongly acidic HZSM-5 [69]. 2) The released H2 from aromatization might increase the local partial pressure of H2 over FeC x sites and in turn enhance the possibility of hydrogenation of the CH2 groups formed on FeC x into CH4. However, over the metal-free HZSM-5 the released H2 is mainly transferred to olefins to form alkanes by H transfer reaction [13]. 3) The added HZSM-5 zeolite may affect the catalytic behavior of FeMn catalyst in the FTS. It is generally accepted that addition of electron-donor alkalis such as Na and K into Fe-based catalyst can lower the selectivity to CH4 and suppress the hydrogenation in the FTS reaction, and therefore increases the selectivity to olefins as well as the possibility of chain propagation [33]. The HZSM-5 which is an acidic material can play the opposite role in the FTS reaction, compared to K. Therefore, the third reason should be primarily responsible for the increase in the selectivity to CH4. As shown in Table 4, As K added into Fe catalyst the CH4 selectivity was greatly reduced from 18.8% (over 100Fe catalyst) to only 10.1%. The HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) was respectively mixed with 100Fe and 99.2Fe0.8K catalysts, however, leaded to a different evolution in the CH4 selectivity. This can be certainly ascribed to the different effects of K and HZSM-5. In the 99.2Fe0.8K-HZSM-5 hybrid catalyst system, the K addition counteracted the negative effect of HZSM-5 in a certain degree, and therefore the CH4 selectivity did not increase in such system. From the Table 2 it can be seen that the CH4 selectivity was also influenced by various reaction conditions. Increasing of reaction temperature resulted in an increase in CH4 selectivity and this can be mainly ascribed to increasing rates of both hydrogenation of CH2 on FeC x phases. High reaction pressure leaded to a decrease greatly in the CH4 selectivity and this is in line with our previous observation [33]. Low reaction pressure leaded to a low CH2 concentration which gives rise to a low possibility for chain propagation but for direct hydrogenation into CH4. High pressure could promote the chain propagation of CH2 groups, which reduced the possibility of its direct hydrogenation into CH4. By comparison, raising the H2/CO ratio in syngas feed only certainly enhanced the hydrogenation reaction (Table 2) to result in a higher selectivity to CH4. CO2 is a typical by-product in the Fe-based FTS reaction, while its formation routes including WGS (CO + H2O = CO2 + H2) over Fe oxide phase and CO disproportionation reaction (2CO = C* + CO2) are still under debate. In this study, the selectivity to CO2 might be related to the WGS reaction. At low level of CO conversion obtained at various reaction conditions, the CO2 selectivity was also low. This should be ascribed to low consumption of H2 with CO into hydrocarbons and then relatively high H2 pressure suppresses the WGS reaction, namely decreases the CO2 selectivity. 4 Conclusion In summary, direct synthesis of aromatics from syngas (CO + H2) has been demonstrated over a hybrid catalyst system composed of Fe-based FTS catalyst and HZSM-5 zeolite. The obtained aromatics was highly selective in the liquid hydrocarbon phase with a common content greater than 95% and the remained gaseous hydrocarbons were close to the component of LPG which could be used as fuel or for further aromatization. In order to elucidate the crucial aspects related to the aromatic formation and distribution, varied reaction conditions including temperature, pressure, space velocity and H2/CO ratio, and catalyst combinations including Si/Al ratio of zeolite, weight ratio of HZSM-5 to Fe-based catalyst, metal modification of HZSM-5, and kind of Fe-based catalyst were systematically investigated first for evaluating their effects on the CO conversion, selectivity to aromatics, their content in liquid phase, aromatic distribution, and catalyst deactivation. HZSM-5 zeolite is the crucial component for aromatic formation. Excessive loading of the zeolite in bed would greatly suppress the carburization of reduced Fe into Fe carbides as well as CO dissociation on the Fe carbides, resulting in a remarkably lower CO conversion. An acidic environment supplied by HZSM-5 zeolite does not benefit those processes over Fe catalysts with the increasingly unfavorable direct contact between the HZSM-5 and Fe-based catalyst, while usually alkaline promoters could promote the CO dissociation and metallic Fe’s carburization obviously. HZSM-5 zeolite having high Brønsted acidity, i.e., with low Si/Al ratio, favors the formation of aromatics with a high content in liquid phase, but also promotes cracking reaction which results in a relatively low selectivity to aromatics. By comparison, zeolite with a high Si/Al ratio increased the iso-paraffins formation in liquid phase, decreasing the aromatic content. Similarly, as HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) deactivated due to coke deposition under several special conditions, isomerization than aromatization gradually dominates in the reactions, also lowering the aromatic content but increasing the iso-paraffins content in liquid phase. Coke deposition on zeolite, especially in the zeolite channels, is the main cause for the decrease in the aromatic synthesis, while the migration of alkaline K promoter to zeolite or extraction of framework Al by in situ formed H2O and CO2 could be ignorable in the study. Reactions operated over FeMn-HZSM-5 catalyst system at lower temperature or higher pressure led to an easier deactivation mainly from coke deposition. Compared with the FeMn-HZSM-5, FeK-HZSM-5 deactivated seriously at same conditions probably due to heavier and olefinic primary hydrocarbons over the FeK catalyst. Increasing of reaction temperature over FeMn-HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 12.5) catalyst system enhanced cracking reaction, while increasing of the H2/CO ratio promoted the hydrogenation of primary olefins, both obviously raising the selectivity to light paraffins. Varying the space velocity or introduction of metal into zeolite showed slight influence on the selectivities to hydrocarbons, the aromatic content in liquid phase and catalyst deactivation, except the CO conversion. In most cases, about 70–90% of aromatics were concentrated on toluene, xylene and 3C-brached alkylbenzenes (mainly ethyl-methyl-benzene). Higher Si/Al ratio of zeolite or lower reaction temperature showed increased fractions for xylene, 3C- and 4C-brached alkylbenzenes but decreased fractions for benzene, toluene, and naphthalene and its derivatives. Although different Fe-based FTS catalysts showed originally different olefins’ and paraffins’ distribution, the obtained aromatic distributions were much similar probably due to the secondary reactions (hydrocracking and hydro-isomerization, for example) of FTS product to produce similar intermediates for subsequent aromatization over HZSM-5 zeolite with higher Brønsted acidity. coredata.dc:description: Direct conversion of syngas (CO + H2) toward aromatics has been demonstrated over a hybrid catalyst system composed of Fe-based FTS catalyst and HZSM-5 zeolite. Over the catalyst system, the aromatics were highly selective in the liquid hydrocarbon products with a content greater than 95%, and 70–90% of the aromatics were concentered on the toluene, xylene and 3C-branched alkylbenzenes. In this study, we systematically investigated the effects of reaction conditions (temperature, pressure, space velocity and H2/CO ratio) and catalyst combination (Si/Al ratio of zeolite, weight ratio of HZSM-5 to Fe-based catalyst, metal modification of HZSM-5, and kind of Fe-based catalyst) on the CO conversion, selectivity to aromatics, aromatic distribution, and catalyst deactivation, combining with some characterization technologies (XRD, BET, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, TG and 27Al NMR). The obtained results show that HZSM-5 zeolite was the crucial component for aromatic formation. Excessive loading of the zeolite in bed would greatly suppress the carburization of reduced Fe into Fe carbides as well as CO dissociation on the Fe carbides because of the increasingly unfavorable direct contact between the acidic HZSM-5 and Fe-based catalyst, resulting in a remarkably lower CO conversion. HZSM-5 zeolite having high Brønsted acidity favored the formation of aromatics with a high content in liquid phase. However, as HZSM-5 had originally lower Brønsted acidity or the Brønsted acidity decreased during the aromatic synthesis due to more coke deposition, the selectivity to hydrocarbons in liquid phase gradually shifted to iso-paraffins rather than aromatics. Reactions operated over FeMn-HZSM-5 catalyst system at lower temperature or higher pressure led to an easier deactivation of HZSM-5 mainly from coke deposition. Compared with the FeMn-HZSM-5, FeK-HZSM-5 deactivated seriously at same conditions probably due to heavier and olefinic primary hydrocarbons over the FeK catalyst. In addition, 27Al NMR showed that extraction of framework Al by in situ formed H2O and CO2 could be ignorable for the HZSM-5 deactivation. More detailed results and discussion from abundant experimental work on clarifying their effects on the aromatic synthesis can be found in the article.
coredata.dc:title: Conversion of syngas toward aromatics over hybrid Fe-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts and HZSM-5 zeolites
